headline: Nasdaq moves to start 23-hour trading, plans to submit paperwork to SEC
summary: CNBC’s “Closing Bell” team discusses the implications for markets if the Nasdaq starts 23-hour trading.

headline: Nasdaq Wants to Keep Wall Street Awake Almost All Day
summary: The exchange is pushing toward 23-hour trading as global demand for US stocks keeps rising

raw.headline: Nasdaq Wants to Keep Wall Street Awake Almost All Day

headline: Nasdaq moves to make trading nearly 24 hours. Why some on Wall Street say that's a bad idea
summary: Critics argue that formalizing nearly nonstop trading could worsen some of the very problems that plague the structure of equity markets today.

raw.headline: Nasdaq moves to make trading nearly 24 hours. Why some on Wall Street say that's a bad idea

headline: Nasdaq Seeks SEC Approval for 23-Hour Weekday Trading
summary: Nasdaq Inc. asked the US Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to add an additional trading session, from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. ET, to extend trading hours on its stock venues to 23 hours during the work week. Justina Lee reports on Bloomberg Television.

raw.headline: Nasdaq Seeks SEC Approval for 23-Hour Weekday Trading
raw.summary: Nasdaq Inc. asked the US Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to add an additional trading session, from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. ET, to extend trading hours on its stock venues to 23 hours during the work week. Justina Lee reports on Bloomberg Television.

headline: Wall Street Breakfast Podcast: Ford Takes $19.5B EV Reset
summary: Ford shifts EV strategy, takes $19.5B write-down and drops current Lightning production. Nasdaq seeks SEC nod for round-the-clock stock trading - report. Holiday shopping season ramps up.

raw.headline: Wall Street Breakfast Podcast: Ford Takes $19.5B EV Reset
raw.summary: Ford shifts EV strategy, takes $19.5B write-down and drops current Lightning production. Nasdaq seeks SEC nod for round-the-clock stock trading - report. Holiday shopping season ramps up.

headline: Nasdaq Seeks SEC Approval for 23-Hour Trading During Weekdays
summary: The firm asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to add an additional trading session, from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. ET, according to a filing Monday.  “This evolution reflects a simple reality: global investors expect access on their terms, in their time zones, without compromising trust or market integrity,” Chuck Mack, senior vice president of North American markets at Nasdaq, said in an emailed statement.  The exchange joins peers in touting growing interest in trading US stocks outside of traditional market hours, which run from 9:30 a.m. ET to 4 p.m. Market participants outside US trading welcomed the potential for faster pricing on earnings and macroeconomic developments, though they cautioned that near-continuous trading would give investors less time to digest after-hours headlines and may lead to more extreme swings during hours when liquidity is thin.
